chapter.chapter: Two Sins, Two Deaths, Two Confessions
chapter.tagline: Understanding that not all sin leads to death and how confession differs for believers and unbelievers.

questions.q: What are the two kinds of sin mentioned in Scripture?
questions.a: The first is the sin unto death—Adam’s inherited sin nature. The second is sin not unto death—acts committed by ignorance or weakness. The former is removed by Christ’s sacrifice; the latter by continual fellowship.

questions.q: What is meant by 'sin unto death'?
questions.a: It refers to Adam’s sin that brought spiritual death on all mankind. Only Jesus’ death and resurrection dealt with it once and for all.

questions.q: Can a believer commit the sin unto death?
questions.a: No. The believer is no longer in Adam but in Christ. He has passed from death to life; sin unto death cannot be imputed to him.

questions.q: What happens when a believer sins after salvation?
questions.a: He doesn’t lose salvation but breaks fellowship. The remedy is confession of faith, not begging for forgiveness, since sin was already judged in Christ.

questions.q: Why do some still confess sins daily?
questions.a: Because they mistake relationship for fellowship. Salvation is permanent; fellowship is maintained by acknowledging truth, not repeated guilt.

questions.q: What are the two types of confession?
questions.a: The sinner confesses Jesus as Lord for salvation. The saint confesses his faith in what Christ has done, not his faults for forgiveness.

questions.q: What does 1 John 1:9 really mean for believers?
questions.a: It’s not a sinner’s repentance verse but a restoration verse for fellowship. Confession here means agreeing with God’s truth, not re-crucifying Jesus.
Confession doesn’t cleanse; the blood already has. Confession aligns the believer with the cleansing that’s already a finished work.

questions.q: What does it mean that there are two deaths?
questions.a: The first death is spiritual separation from God; the second is physical death. Jesus died both spiritually and physically to conquer both for us.

questions.q: Why must believers understand these two confessions?
questions.a: Because wrong confession produces fear and guilt. Right confession affirms identity in Christ, keeping the believer established in grace.
